creditline: Gift from the Minneapolis Institute of Arts Collectors' Club
inscription:
Signature; Inscription; Mark
on front edge of base: [ICARE. D'apred la statue en bronze detruite en 1870 á Strasbourg];
markings: on back of base, foundry mark: Eck et Durand on back of base.
medium: Bronze, casting history and edition size unknown
text: In Greek legend, King Minos imprisoned Daedalus and his son Icarus on the island of Crete as punishment for assisting the escape of the hero Theseus. A master craftsman, Daedalus constructed wings of wax and feathers to help the pair escape. Though warned by his father not to fly too close to the sun, Icarus cannot resist the temptation and plunges to his death when his wings melt. In this reduction of the life-sized original for the Paris Salon of 1831, Grasse depicts the young man at the moment of takeoff, arms straining upward and wings poised for flight.
title: Icarus Making Trial of His Wings
